column4: slart: it give this message E: dpkg was interrupted, you must manually run 'dpkg --configure -a' to correct the problem.
E: dpkg was interrupted, you must manually run 'dpkg --configure -a' to correct the problem.
slart: i did
slart:http://paste.ubuntu-nl.org/35237/plain/
Did you run it as root? ( with sudo ) ?
What happened after you entered the needed information?
What is wrong with it?
I assume that it is not using the full resolution and so there is black to fill the extra space
Why are you addressing me specifically?
Just ask your question but don't address it to anyone specifically, if anyone can help they will
What GFX card do you have?
Did you ever say what Graphics card you have?
Check in System -> Administration -> Restricted Driver Manager
By the time you were through you would have to start over for the next release :)

With Linux there is less of a seperation between "the OS" and applications that run "on top of" the OS, to get "everything that Ubuntu has to offer" you would have to download all the hundreds of thousands of packages / applications available :)
Actually more like 21,000 but you get the point :)
Your memory being full is a good thing, it means that data that you use frequently is kept in RAM, unused RAM is waisted RAM ( and the RAM will be reclaimed as soon as any application needs it )
It sits in RAM not being used or it is taken out of RAM to make room for more important data
I don't know, why would you want to?
There is nothing wrong with things staying in RAM
I am sure there is, but since there is no real reason for it it is probably not easy
